thread.title: Dow jumps triple digits as Street cheers Greece, China
thread.title_full: Dow jumps triple digits as Street cheers Greece, China

title: Dow jumps triple digits as Street cheers Greece, China
text:
Dow jumps triple digits as Street cheers Greece, China By Evelyn Cheng 9 minutes ago ÓÅ± . View photo Lucas Jackson | Reuters. U.S. stocks surged as a second day of recovery in Chinese stocks and hopes of a resolution in Greece boosted investor sentiment. 
U.S. stocks surged on Friday as a second day of recovery in Chinese stocks and hopes of a resolution in Greece boosted investor sentiment. ( Tweet This ) 
The Dow Jones industrial average attempted gains for the week, trading about 160 points higher. 
The index jumped more than 200 points in the open as the major averages leaped nearly 1 percent or more. The Dow transports also gained more than 1.5 percent led by airlines. 
"This has been a week where everyone worried about China and Greece and as we go into the weekend those big financial headwinds are less scary," said David Kelly, chief global strategist at JPMorgan Funds. "There's clearly more optimism that a a Greece deal (is reached)." 
Greece submitted new reform proposals late Thursday that creditors could evaluate as early as Friday . The parliament in Athens is also scheduled to vote on the proposals later in the day. 
Chinese stocks extended gains on Friday , jumping for a second day following government intervention amid hopes of a Greece deal. 
Traders will also listen to Fed Chair Janet Yellen's midday speech for signals on when the central bank might raise rates, especially given the recent developments in Greece and China. 
Analysts said the bond market will likely react the most to Yellen's comments. 
Yields were already higher in morning trade amid some relief on overseas pressures. The U.S. 10-year note yield was near 2.39 percent and the 2-year yield at 0.63 percent. German 10-year bund yields leaped to 0.88 percent. 
The U.S. dollar fell more than 1 percent, with the euro approaching $1.12. 
"The likelihood of a Grexit has dramatically diminished," said Doug Cote, chief market strategist at Voya Investment Management. "Despite the volatility, despite the noise from Greece we're having good fundamental data coming out in (U.S.) housing. ... The fundamentals continue to drive this market forward." 
In economic reports, U.S. wholesale trade inventories for May jumped 0.8 percent, soundly topping estimates for the fastest pace of growth in six months. April's figure was unchanged, showing a 0.4 percent gain. 
There are no major earnings due on Friday. 
Stocks rallied sharply in the open Thursday but gave back the majority of their gains to close mildly higher as lack of resolution on Greece kept investors on edge. 
The Dow Jones Industrial Average (Dow Jones Global Indexes: .DJI) traded up 195 points, or 1.10 percent, at 17,741, with Verizon ( VZ ) leading all blue chips higher. 
The S&P 500 ( ^GSPC ) traded up 22 points, or 1.07 percent, at 2,073, with telecommunications leading all sectors higher. 
The Nasdaq ( ^IXIC ) traded up 57 points, or 1.15 percent, at 4,979. 
The CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) ( ^VIX ) , widely considered the best gauge of fear in the market, traded just below 18. 
About six stocks advanced for every decliner on the New York Stock Exchange, with an exchange volume of 122 million and a composite volume of 443 million as of 10:06 a.m. 
Crude oil futures for August delivery fell 12 cents to $52.66 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Gold futures fell 10 cents to $1,159.10 an ounce in morning trade. 
Read More Early movers: BUD, COTY, GPS, CUDA, IHG, WBA & more 
Gap ( GPS ) reported a 1 percent drop in June same-store sales, more than the Thomson Reuters estimate for a 0.5 percent decline. 
Barracuda Networks ( CUDA ) beat estimates by 1 cent with adjusted quarterly profit of 9 cents per share, with revenue also above estimates. However, gross billings-a sign of future demand-were well below Street forecasts. 
- CNBC's Peter Schacknow contributed to this report. 
On tap this week:
